Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: The Impact of Reward on Large-Scale Functional Brain Networks: An Interdisciplinary Approach to Understanding the Motivated Brain

POR.DRECONTENT:
Motivation drives behavior, and research has demonstrated that motivation can affect how individuals perceive their environments, evaluate items, make decisions, and can even determine how and what they learn. Given motivation’s pervasive and influential effects on a variety of behaviors, a goal of psychology and neuroscience has been to understand its underlying neural mechanisms. It is known that the dopaminergic neuromodulatory system, including the ventral tegmental area (VTA) and the nucleus accumbens (nACC), play a critical role in mediating motivated behavior. Most human research has investigated the behavioral and psychological factors that modulate activity in these regions in isolation; with relatively less research investigating how these regions interact with each other and other brain regions during motivated behaviors.  

In collaboration with Dr. Michael Chee at the National University of Singapore and Dr. Alison Adcock at Duke University, I explored how reward motivation affected connectivity between the VTA, nACC, and other neural regions. I was able to examine how the context of reward changed connectivity strengths between the VTA and the rest of the brain. Given the nature of functional neuroimaging data, we defined connectivity as the correlated activity between two brain regions as a function of task demands. We found that within the context of reward there was enhanced connectivity of the VTA with the nACC, as well as other critical brain regions like the prefrontal cortex. Future studies will investigate how the context of reward affects other measures of connectivity, such as causal modeling amongst regions and large-scale functional networks across the whole brain (i.e. small world network connectivity).
